data.title: Use Settings Editor Viewer for Editing Keybindings
data.body: While editing my keybinding today, I noticed the editing experience is inconsistent when compared to editing settings. Is it possible make the settings and keybinding editing view and experience the same.

data.title: Indentations getting lost while copy pasting
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.11.0-insider (6a002910356c6e087dd93e819e4ad54c68b9857a, 2017-03-15T07:11:58.965Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.10586
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|vscode-great-icons|emmanuelbeziat|1.1.44|
|Theme-azure|gerane|0.0.2|
|easy-icons|jamesmaj|0.3.1|
|jostheme|jestersimpps|0.1.0|
|theme-onedark-sublime|joshpeng|0.3.6|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1.The copy as HTML with syntax highlighting was working awesome. But after a couple of updates, now the same when copy pasting, looses all the indentations. 
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5024456/23945233/cadd63b6-099b-11e7-852e-bccc9bd6d5b1.png)

2. I was able to copy paste well before, but now, after pasting, i need to again re-align the braces and spacings.

data.title: Remember Language Mode for re-opened hot-exit code
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

Would it be possible to restore the Language mode that was set on an unsaved file when restoring ?

- VSCode Version: 1.11.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 1607

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a new file, don't save
2. Set language mode to anything but "Plain Text"
3. Exit without saving
4. Re-open VS Code
5. Code is restored in Untitled-1, language mode is back to "Plain Text"

data.title: Incorrect syntax highlighting when a varible name ends with 'var' in Go mode
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.11.0-insider & 1.10.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create/Open a code file written in Go
2. Choose `Go` as the current syntax highlighting mode
3. Write a function definition as follows:
```go
func fnName(avar string, bval bool, cvar int, dval rune) { }
``` 
Or, a varible definition as follows:
```go
var aval, bvar string
``` 
On either case above, the syntax highlighting goes wrong after the varible whose name ends with `var`. Snapshots are listed below:
![1 10 2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1275238/23941086/77056e12-09a2-11e7-9962-341257bd4dab.png)
![1 11 0](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1275238/23940988/f9cb3396-09a1-11e7-8794-8884d64311de.png)

The reason should be caused by misinterpretting the trailing part of a varible name (`var`) as the keyword `var`.

data.title: Cannot close miniterm
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.11.0-insider (1.11.0-insider)
- OS Version: Mac OSX Sierra

Steps to Reproduce:

1. I've got pyserial and miniterm installed together with ESP32-IDF (https://github.com/espressif/esp-idf)
2. If I want to compile and flash and run a console I need to issue 

`make flash monitor`

on a terminal prompt. This works both, on native terminal and integrated terminal. But I can't finish the terminal after debugging. The key combination is CTRL-[, which is CTRL+ALT+6 on a Mac. This closes the miniterm window in native terminal, but not in integrated terminal in VSCode

data.title: Debugging OSS builds fail after 3-7-17 master branch code, silent failure, cannot breakpoint
data.body:
Development Environment:

OS: Windows 7 Professional SP1 (VM under OSX)
Python: ActiveState 2.7.5

Visual Studio 15 Community \ C++ Tools \ SDK 8.1
VS Code: 1.10.2 (Code OSS Build environment)
VS Code Insiders 1.11.0 3-13 build: (Test environment)
Chrome Debugger Extension 2.6.0


Node: 6.9.1
NPM:  3.10.8

Debug Issue:

I have multiple local repositories for VSC code source trees.
I have done this to keep things separate while experimenting and learning.
the problem I am having is that only one local repository of VSC
can be debuged. I have three repositories all that can Build
and successfully execute. all have changes and some debug output
the launch files are all the same an original from the VSC clone.

if I launch the debugger with breakpoints in my main repository
the code launches and debugging will successfully work including breakpoints.

if I launch any other code from another repository, the OSS Dev
version launches but the debugger shows no output in the debug output
window and breakpoints are never hit. No debug errors our ever displayed
the debugger buttons appear as normal.

I'm thinking that there is something non- volatile saved by the one
working repository that interferes with the others. I have tried
full cleans changing names in product.jason without success.

I do think the one working repository was the first I did a win32-package
operation. One of the last tests was to do a clean of the Win32 package.
That still did not work.

I don't know how to get anymore log info as the debug output
is totally blank. And the builder works just fine.

Update:

- did exact folder copy of working repository - this works and dbg works correctly
- did fresh clone of master vsc in fresh repository/folder - build and execute okay
cannot debug - no errors F6 to pause process takes a long time but finally stops in
net.js - no source debugging/or error log output

- found I had another repository where debugging works , was cloned from 2-24-17
- repository clone from 3-1 works, each repository 3-10 and my later forks
all will not work with dbg but build and execute

Thanks
Christopher

data.title: Tilde in url in terminal results in bad url
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.3

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a bash script named `foo.sh` with the following contents

```bash
#/bin/bash
echo https://deb.nodesource.com/node_6.x/pool/main/n/nodejs/nodejs_6.10.0-1nodesource1~xenial1_amd64.debc
```

2. Make the file executable then execute it.

The link is clickable (cmd + click) in the text file, but the terminal only detects the first part (up to the tilde) as a url.

data.title: C# / Unity code using LINQ breaks the debugger
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.3

When using the Unity3D / C# debugging feature in VSCode, if you place a breakpoint inside code that is triggered by LINQ queries, Unity will pause and the debugger will hit the breakpoint, but the breakpointed line isn't highlighted and no debug information is shown in the debug panel. The only action you can take is to press continue, after which everything goes back to normal.

Outside of LINQ code, the debugger works fine.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Write a function that is called inside of a LINQ query (such as `lead.Serialize()` in `this._leads.Select(lead => lead.Serialize()).ToList()`).
2. Inside the function, place a breakpoint.
3. Attach VSCode debugger to Unity3D and hit the breakpoint.

data.title: Allow window title color to distinguish between multiple windows
data.body: I often have multiple directories open in separate VSCode windows, and wish I could at a glance distinguish between them (like with a random color present in the UI)although the directory name is already in the title of the window, it often takes me a bit to reorient myself because there is so much text on screen already. Any suggestions on how to more easily distinguish between multiple open files/a possibility to include a feature like this?

data.title: Avoid/Undo Broken Extensions
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.9.0 (27240e71ef390bf2d66307e677c2a333cebf75af, 2017-02-02T08:23:30.856Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.4.0
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|Go|lukehoban|0.6.53|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. When an extension author's pushes a build that is failing, you can see it in Extensions
2. Update & it will be broken.

I would like avoidance & undo:
Avoid:  Detect the "build failing" logo on github & stop offering it as an upgrade
Undo:  Let me return to a previous extension version if the present one isn't working.
